page.title: 16HOLME VALLEY HOUSING (1)
page.content:
In the small area of the Holme Valley, covered by our 'D block', there are examples of a wide variety of domestic buildings. In Honley's conservation area, and in the surrounding countryside, are houses and farms dating to the 17th C. These are built in local grit stone with stone flagged rooves. In the 18th and 19th C. stone built homes were provided in the valley bottom for the workers of the textile mills. Terraces of these small homes remain. From the same period are the larger detached homes of the middle class, including the mill owners. After the arrival of the railways, in the 1850s, slate became the usual roofing material.
